Identification.LongTitle: Rules Governing the Proceedings, Practice and Procedures of the Canadian International Trade Tribunal

Provision.Text: His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Finance, pursuant to subsection 39(1)* of the Canadian International Trade Tribunal Act**, is pleased hereby to approve

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: the revocation by the Canadian International Trade Tribunal of the Canadian Import Tribunal Rules, approved by Order in Council P.C. 1985-3312 of November 7, 1985***; and

Footnote.Text: SOR/85-1068, 1985 Canada Gazette Part II, p. 4652

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: the making by the Canadian International Trade Tribunal, after consultation with the Minister of Finance, of the annexed Rules governing the proceedings, practice and procedures of the Canadian International Trade Tribunal, in substitution therefor.

Section.Text: These Rules may be cited as the Canadian International Trade Tribunal Rules.
In these Rules,

Definition.Text: Act means the Canadian International Trade Tribunal Act; (Loi)
address includes an address for electronic transmission; (adresse)
appeal means an appeal referred to in paragraph 30(a); (appel)
appellant means a person who files a notice of appeal pursuant to rule 31; (appelant)
counsel includes any person who acts in a proceeding on behalf of a party; (avocat)
counsel of record means the counsel of record for a party as determined in accordance with rule 11; (avocat inscrit au dossier)

document means a submission, affidavit or any other documentary material, regardless of physical form or medium, including any correspondence, memorandum, book, plan, map, drawing, diagram, pictorial or graphic work, photograph, film, microform, sound recording, videotape and machine readable record, and any copy, in whole or in part, of that material; (document)

electronic hearing means a hearing held by telephone or video conference, or by any other electronic means by which parties can communicate with each other and the Tribunal orally; (audience électronique)
electronic transmission includes communication by fax, by email or by means of the Tribunal website (e-filing); (transmission électronique)
hearing by way of written submissions means a hearing held by the exchange of documents; (audience sur pièces)
interested party, in relation to an inquiry under section 42 or 45 of the Special Import Measures Act or a review under section 76.01, 76.02, 76.03 or 76.1 of that Act, means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the complainant, if any, under section 31 of that Act in the investigation in which the preliminary determination referred to in section 42 of that Act was made,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any domestic producer, exporter to Canada or importer into Canada of goods in respect of which the preliminary determination was made,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an association of, or that includes, domestic producers, exporters to Canada or importers into Canada of goods in respect of which the preliminary determination was made,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the government of any country mentioned in the preliminary determination,

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: a trade union that represents persons employed in the domestic industry producing like goods or directly competitive goods or an association that includes such trade unions; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other person who, because their rights or pecuniary interests may be affected or for any other reason, is entitled to be heard by the Tribunal before the Tribunal disposes of the inquiry or the review, as the case may be, in accordance with that Act; (partie intéressée)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has filed a request to intervene and has been added as an intervener under rule 41, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is an interested party that has been granted leave of the Tribunal to intervene in any proceedings in relation to a complaint under section 30.17 of the Act; (intervenant)

Definition.Text: other interested party has the same meaning as in section 3 of the Canadian International Trade Tribunal Regulations; (autres intéressés)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an inquiry under section 42 or 45 of the Special Import Measures Act or a review under section 76.01, 76.02, 76.03 or 76.1 of that Act, an interested party who has filed a notice of participation in the inquiry or review, as the case may be, in accordance with these Rules,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a proceeding under section 89 or paragraph 91(1)(g) of the Special Import Measures Act, a person to whom notice has been sent under subrule 76(2) or rule 79, if the person has

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: filed a notice of participation in accordance with these Rules, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if no hearing is to be held in the proceeding, made a written submission to the Tribunal,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an appeal, the appellant, the respondent or an intervener,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a complaint under subsection 30.11(1) of the Act, the complainant, the government institution or an intervener, and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of any other proceeding, a person who has an interest in the subject-matter of the proceeding and who has

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: filed a notice of participation in that proceeding in accordance with these Rules, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: been given status by the Tribunal to be a party in that proceeding; (partie)

Definition.Text: proceeding includes an appeal, re-hearing, reference, inquiry, recommencement of inquiry, review, request for a ruling, reconsideration of an order or finding, complaint filed by a domestic producer or any other proceeding before the Tribunal under the Act or under any other Act of Parliament or regulations made thereunder; (procédure)
request to intervene includes an appearance referred to in subsection 67(2) of the Customs Act or subsection 61(2) of the Special Import Measures Act; (demande d’intervention)
respondent means the Minister of National Revenue or the President, as the case may be. (intimé)

Section.Text: These Rules shall be liberally construed to secure the fairest, least expensive and most expeditious determination of every proceeding, in accordance with section 35 of the Act.
Except where the context otherwise requires, this Part applies to all proceedings before the Tribunal.

If a question of procedure arises that is not covered or not fully covered in these Rules, the question must be disposed of in a manner that the Tribunal directs and that is consistent with any of these Rules that are applicable and that considerations of procedural fairness permit.

The Tribunal may dispense with, vary or supplement any of these Rules if it is fair and equitable to do so or to provide for a more expeditious or informal process, as the circumstances and considerations of fairness permit.

The Tribunal may, on its own initiative or on the written request of a party, combine two or more proceedings to provide for a more expeditious or informal process, as the circumstances and considerations of fairness permit.
No proceeding is invalid by reason of a defect in form or a technical irregularity.
If it is fair and equitable to do so, the Tribunal may extend or abridge the time limits fixed by these Rules or otherwise fixed by the Tribunal, either before or after their expiry.
Unless otherwise provided, the computation of time under these Rules or a direction of the Tribunal is governed by sections 26 to 28 of the Interpretation Act.

Subsection.Text: A person who proposes to participate in a proceeding, other than a proceeding under Part II or Part X, shall file with the Tribunal a notice of participation on the relevant Tribunal form on or before the date that is specified in the notice published in the Canada Gazette under rule 54, 65, 71, 73.1, 73.5, 76, 78 or 85, as the case may be.

If a person referred to in subrule (1) sets out, in the notice of participation, the name of the counsel by whom they will be represented, the counsel shall file with the Tribunal a notice of representation on the relevant Tribunal form on or before the date that is specified in the notice published in the Canada Gazette under rule 54, 65, 71, 73.1, 73.5, 76, 78 or 85, as the case may be.

A counsel who signs a document filed pursuant to these Rules on behalf of any party shall be the counsel of record for the party commencing on the date of filing and continuing until a change, if any, is made in accordance with subrule (2).
A party in a proceeding may change the party’s counsel of record by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: filing with the Tribunal a Notice of Change of counsel of record signed by the new counsel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: serving a copy of the Notice on the former counsel and every other party in the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: filing with the Tribunal proof of service of the Notice.

Subsection.Text: The parties must file their documents by electronic transmission.
The Tribunal may, if it considers that it is justified in the circumstances, allow paper filing.
Documents filed by electronic transmission shall constitute the original.
A party may make a written request to the Tribunal to file a document as a single copy exhibit.
A document that is filed by fax must be accompanied by a cover page setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sender’s name, postal and email addresses, and telephone and fax numbers ;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of pages transmitted, including the cover page;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the title or description of the document transmitted; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and email address of a person to contact if transmission problems occur.

Subsection.Text: A document that is filed by email must be accompanied by an electronic message setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sender’s name, telephone number, postal and email addresses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the title or description of the document transmitted; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and email address of a person to contact if transmission problems occur.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subrule 31(3) and rule 96, the date of filing of a document is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the document is filed by electronic transmission, the date of transmission; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, the date on which the document is received by the Tribunal, as evidenced by the date stamped on it.

Subsection.Text: If a statement made under oath or affirmation is filed by electronic transmission, it must include a handwritten signature and the following statement: “The document that is being submitted by electronic transmission to the Tribunal is an electronic version of a paper document that has been signed by the affiant. The signed document in paper copy is available and will be produced if requested by the Tribunal.”
The party filing the statement must keep the signed document in paper copy until one year after all time limits for appeals expire.
On the Tribunal’s request, the party filing the statement must provide the signed document in paper copy for review.
Subject to subrule (2), all documents filed with the Tribunal must be in English or French.

A person may file an original document in a language other than English or French if, at the same time, the person also files a translation of it in English or French and an affidavit attesting to the accuracy of the translation. If the document is required to be served, the translation and affidavit must be served at the same time.
Subject to rule 17 and in addition to the provisions of the Excise Tax Act in respect of appeals under Part VII of that Act, the following rules apply to the service of documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if a document is required to be served personally, the service shall be made

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on an individual, by leaving a copy of it with the individual,

Subparagraph.Label: (i.1)
Subparagraph.Text: on a general partnership, by leaving a copy of it with one of the partners,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on a corporation, by leaving a copy of it with an officer, director or agent of the corporation, or with a person at any place of business of the corporation who appears to manage or be in control of the place of business, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any other case, in any manner that the Tribunal determines is just and equitable in the circumstances; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a document is not required to be served personally, the service shall be made at the address for service of the party.

Subsection.Text: The address for service of a party shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where there is a counsel of record for a party, the business address of the counsel as shown on the most recent document filed by the counsel that shows the counsel’s address; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where there is no counsel of record

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of the Minister of National Revenue or the President, the Office of the Deputy Attorney General of Canada in Ottawa, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of any other party, the address of the party as shown on the most recent document filed by the party that shows the party’s address.

Subsection.Text: The service of a document at an address for service must be made by sending it to the address for service by hand, mail, registered mail, courier or electronic transmission.
A document that is served by fax must be accompanied by a cover page setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sender’s name, postal and email addresses and telephone and fax numbers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person to be served;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of pages transmitted, including the cover page;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the title or description of the document transmitted; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and email address of a person to contact if transmission problems occur.

Subsection.Text: A document that is served by email must be accompanied by an electronic message setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sender’s name, telephone number, postal and email addresses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person to be served;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the title or description of the document transmitted; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and email address of a person to contact if transmission problems occur.

Subsection.Text: In the absence of proof to the contrary, the date of service of a document is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the document is served personally, the date of delivery;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the document is served by mail or registered mail, the date that is five days after the earliest postal date appearing on the envelope containing the document;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the document is served by electronic transmission, the date of the transmission; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the document is served by courier, the date of receipt indicated on the courier receipt.

Subsection.Text: If a document is required under these Rules to be served by a party or by direction of the Tribunal, the Tribunal may direct that a proof of service be filed with the Tribunal.
A proof of service of a document shall be made by showing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an acknowledgement of service signed by or on behalf of the person served; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an affidavit of service stating the name of the person who served the document and the date, place and manner of service.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise provided by these Rules or any other law, any sending, transmitting, notifying, servicing or filing may be done by hand, mail, registered mail, courier or electronic transmission.

If a document is filed by electronic transmission and a certified copy of the document is requested from the Tribunal, the Tribunal may provide an electronic copy, stamped “certified ”, of the document.

Where information designated as confidential pursuant to paragraph 85(1)(a) of the Special Import Measures Act is filed with the Tribunal, the Tribunal shall treat that information as confidential unless the person who provided it agrees in writing that it need not be treated as confidential by the Tribunal.

Subsection.Text: A document that contains information designated as confidential under section 46 of the Act must be marked “CONFIDENTIAL” in capital letters on each page and the confidential information must be placed between square brackets and highlighted.

Confidential information must be redacted in the non-confidential edited version of the document marked “CONFIDENTIAL” in capital letters. The version that contains the confidential information and the non-confidential edited version must be in the same format, including page and paragraph numbering and lines per page.

Except for the purpose of Parts II and X, the filing of the documents referred to in this rule is completed when all of them have been filed and, if they are filed on different dates, the date of filing is the date on which the most recent document is filed.

Heading.TitleText: Disclosure of Information to Counsel or to Expert

Subsection.Text: A counsel for a party who wishes to have access to confidential information under subsection 45(3) of the Act must provide the Tribunal with a declaration and undertaking on the relevant Tribunal form in respect of the use, disclosure, reproduction, protection and storage of the information in the record of a proceeding, as well as in respect of that counsel’s disposal of the information at the close of the proceeding or in the event of a change of counsel.

An expert who wishes to have access to confidential information under subsection 45(3) or (3.1) of the Act must provide the Tribunal with a declaration and undertaking on the relevant Tribunal form in respect of the use, disclosure, reproduction, protection and storage of the confidential information in the record of a proceeding, as well as in respect of that expert’s disposal of the confidential information at the close of the proceeding or in the event of a change of expert.
Any party or interested person may request, by way of motion in accordance with rule 24, that the Tribunal not disclose some or all of the confidential information to a counsel or expert.

The Tribunal must notify the counsel or the expert, as the case may be, of its decision as to whether to disclose the confidential information and on what terms and conditions that disclosure would be made.

Heading.TitleText: Filing and Communication of Confidential Information

Subsection.Text: Subject to any other provisions of these Rules, confidential information shall be filed with the Tribunal and may be served only by the Tribunal.

Despite subrule (1), a counsel for a party to a proceeding who has filed confidential information with the Tribunal may, in accordance with written directions issued by the Tribunal, serve that information on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a counsel who is acting on behalf of another party in the same proceeding, who has filed a declaration and undertaking under rule 16 and who has been granted access to that information; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an expert who is acting under the control or direction of a counsel acting on behalf of another party in the same proceeding, who has filed a declaration and undertaking under rule 16 and who has been granted access to that information.

Subsection.Text: At the time of giving notice of a hearing to be held in any proceeding or at any time after the giving of that notice, the Tribunal may direct that all parties to the proceeding or their counsel appear before the Tribunal or before a member, at a day, time and place fixed by the Tribunal, for a pre-hearing conference for the purpose of making representations, settling questions of procedure or merit before the hearing or receiving guidance from the Tribunal with respect to any of the following matters:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the clarification and simplification of issues;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure to be followed at the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the mutual exchange between parties to the proceeding of written submissions, exhibits and other material presented or to be presented to the Tribunal;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the question of whether any written submission, other document or testimony presented or proposed to be presented to the Tribunal contains confidential information;

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: the question of whether a person who is to appear on behalf of a party is acknowledged by the parties to be an expert;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the question of the confidential information, if any, to which a person who is to appear on behalf of a party in the capacity of an expert on any matter should be given access; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that is relevant to the proceeding.

Subsection.Text: Counsel for any party to a proceeding may, if notice of a hearing has been given in the proceeding, make a written request to the Tribunal to direct that a pre-hearing conference be held to consider any matter referred in subrule (1).

On receipt of a request referred to in subrule (2), the Tribunal may direct that a pre-hearing conference be held if it determines that a pre-hearing conference would assist in the orderly conduct of the hearing or in settling questions of merit.
The Tribunal may conduct the pre-hearing conference in any manner that gives the parties or their counsel a fair opportunity to participate.

The Tribunal shall, prior to or at the commencement of a hearing in a proceeding, make available to each party or the party’s counsel all of the information that has been provided to the Tribunal for the purposes of the proceeding and that has not been designated as confidential.

The Tribunal must, prior to or at the commencement of a hearing in a proceeding, make all confidential information that has been provided to the Tribunal or issued by it for the purposes of the proceeding available to each counsel and each expert who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has filed a declaration and undertaking under rule 16; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has been granted access to the information.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may make the information referred to in subrule (1) or (2) available to a party or the party’s counsel by transmitting the documents by hand, mail, courier or electronic transmission.

The Tribunal may, on its own initiative or at the request of any party, summon before it by subpoena any person to attend a hearing and require that person to give evidence on oath or affirmation and to produce documents or other things.
The request must set out the name, postal address and telephone number and, if applicable email address of the party making the request and of the person to be subpoenaed.

A subpoena must be served personally. At the time of service, an amount that is not less than the amount to which the person would have been entitled as fees and allowances, if summoned to attend before the Federal Court, must be paid or tendered to them.
If a subpoena is served on a person, the original copy of the subpoena must be filed with the Tribunal without delay, together with proof of service on the person.
At any time in a proceeding, in order to obtain information, the Tribunal may order that a party or a non-party fill out a questionnaire or respond to a request for information.

The party or the non-party may file with the Tribunal, within three working days after the issuance of the order, a letter explaining why an order should not have been issued or why the requested information cannot reasonably be provided.
If a letter is filed under subrule (2), the matter must be disposed of in accordance with any instructions that the Tribunal may give.

Subject to section 34 of the Act and unless these Rules provide otherwise, witnesses at a hearing shall be examined orally on oath or affirmation and the examination may consist of direct examination, cross-examination and re-examination.
The Tribunal may, on its own initiative or on the request of a party, direct that a person file an affidavit in support of any statement made in a proceeding before the Tribunal.
Subject to subrule (3), an affidavit must be confined to a statement of facts within the personal knowledge of the person filing it.
The Tribunal may allow the person to file an affidavit containing a statement of what the person believes to be the facts accompanied by a statement of the grounds by which they are supported.

A party who intends to call an expert as a witness at a hearing must, not less than 30 days before the hearing, file with the Tribunal and serve on the other parties a report, signed by the proposed expert, setting out the proposed expert’s name, postal and email addresses, telephone number, qualifications, area of expertise and a summary of their testimony in sufficient detail to convey a reasonable understanding of it.

A party on whom a report has been served and who wishes to rebut with expert evidence any matter set out in the report must, not less than 20 days before the hearing, file with the Tribunal and serve on the other parties a rebuttal expert report setting out a summary of the rebuttal evidence to be introduced in sufficient detail to convey a reasonable understanding of it.

The rebuttal expert report must be signed by the author of the report and set out their name, postal and email addresses, telephone number, qualifications, area of expertise and a summary of their testimony in sufficient detail to convey a reasonable understanding of it.
The Tribunal may, prior to the commencement of a hearing, direct that parties seek to reach an agreement

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on whether a person has the requisite credentials or qualifications to be considered as an expert; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the proposed area of expertise of that person.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subrule (2), all of the hearings at which the parties or their counsel may appear before the Tribunal are public.
The Tribunal may hold a hearing or any part of one in camera,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on its own initiative or on the request of a party, for the purpose of receiving confidential information; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the request of a party in which the party establishes that the circumstances justify an in camera hearing.

Subsection.Text: When the Tribunal holds a hearing or part of one in camera, the hearing or part may be attended only by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is to present confidential information and anyone whom the person requests be permitted to attend;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: counsel for a party or an expert who has been granted access to confidential information under rule 16;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: employees of the Administrative Tribunals Support Service of Canada who have been directed, at the request of the Tribunal, to attend; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other person whom the Tribunal authorizes to attend.

Subsection.Text: A party who requires oral translation in any given language in order to participate in or have a witness testify at a hearing, other than at a hearing by way of written submissions, must notify the Tribunal in writing of the requirement and of the language of translation, at least 20 days before the hearing.

The Tribunal may permit a party to provide their own oral translation in order to participate in or have a witness testify at a hearing, other than a hearing by way of written submissions, if the party makes a request in writing at least 20 days before the hearing and the Tribunal determines that the use of translation is fair and equitable in the circumstances.
A party may make a request to the Tribunal for a decision or order on any matter that arises in the course of a proceeding.
The party who makes the request shall serve a copy of it on the other parties at the same time as it is filed with the Tribunal.
Before making a determination on the request, the Tribunal must provide an opportunity for the other parties to make representations.
The Tribunal must proceed by way of motion if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it decides not to proceed by way of written request under rule 23.1; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: these Rules so specify.

Subsection.Text: A motion must be in writing and set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a clear and concise statement of the facts, which must be accompanied by an affidavit if the Tribunal so directs; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the decision or order sought and the grounds for seeking it.

Subsection.Text: A motion given by a party must be filed with the Tribunal and served on the other parties not less than five days before the day fixed for the commencement of the hearing.
Any party who wishes to answer a motion must file a written answer with the Tribunal and serve a copy of it on the other parties.

If a party wishes to submit a document in support of a motion or answer, the document must accompany the motion or answer in question and the party must file it with the Tribunal and serve a copy of it on the other parties.
Unless the Tribunal directs otherwise, a decision or order on a motion must be made in writing.

Despite subrules (2) to (5), a motion in connection with a matter that has not come to the attention of a party prior to the commencement of a hearing may be made orally at the hearing and must be disposed of in accordance with any procedure that the Tribunal may direct.
A party may file a motion seeking permission for the late filing of a document or physical exhibit.
The motion is to set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why the document or the physical exhibit was not filed within the applicable time limit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the relevance of the document or physical exhibit to the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why the late filing should be permitted.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may in exceptional circumstances and if it determines that it is fair and equitable in the circumstances, permit the document or the physical exhibit to be filed, in whole or in part during a period that the Tribunal fixes.
The Tribunal must notify the parties of its decision under subrule (3) and the reasons for it.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise required by these Rules, the Tribunal may decide to proceed by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: way of a hearing at which the parties or their counsel appear in person before the Tribunal;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: way of electronic hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: way of a hearing by way of written submissions; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any combination of the ways referred to in paragraphs (a) to (c).

Heading.TitleText: Hearing by Way of Written Submissions

Section.Text: When the Tribunal decides to hold a hearing by way of written submissions, the Tribunal shall publish a notice to that effect and may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: dispose of the matter on the basis of the written documentation before it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: require further information to be furnished by any party; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: invite submissions from any party or any person who may have an interest in the matter.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may, on its own initiative or on the request of a party, postpone or adjourn a hearing, and, in determining whether to grant the request, the Tribunal shall consider, in addition to any other relevant factors, whether a similar issue is being considered before another court whose determination could impact on the matter being heard, whether any prejudice would result if the postponement or adjournment were granted or not granted and whether a postponement or adjournment would unreasonably delay or impede the proceedings.
A request for a postponement must be made at least 15 days before the hearing and must set out the reasons for the postponement.
The Tribunal shall notify the parties of its decision under subrule (1).

Section.Text: Any person who wishes to obtain information in respect of the procedure followed by the Tribunal, or to inspect documents, exhibits or other material provided to it, must make a request to the Tribunal.

Heading.TitleText: Decisions, Orders or Findings of the Tribunal

Subsection.Text: If the Tribunal makes a decision, declaration, determination, recommendation, order, finding or other ruling in a proceeding, the Tribunal must, without delay after it is made, forward, subject to paragraph 43(2)(a), subparagraphs 76.01(6)(a)(i) and 76.02(5)(a)(i) and subsections 76.03(5) and (6) of the Special Import Measures Act, a copy of it to each party and to each person who was provided with a notice of commencement of the proceeding.

The Tribunal must, without delay after the making of a decision, declaration, order, finding or other final ruling in a proceeding, cause a notice to that effect to be published in the Canada Gazette.

If the Tribunal is required by subsection 43(2), paragraph 76.01(6)(a) or 76.02(5)(a) or subsection 76.03(5) of the Special Import Measures Act to send a copy of the order or finding in a proceeding as well as the reasons for making the order or finding to the persons specified in subsection 43(2), paragraph 76.01(6)(a) or 76.02(5)(a) or subsection 76.03(5) of that Act, as the case may be, it must also send a copy to every other person who was provided with a notice of commencement of the proceeding.

Section.Text: Where a party to a proceeding has not met any requirement of these Rules or complied with any order or direction issued by the Tribunal, the Tribunal may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: stay the proceeding until it is satisfied that the requirement has been met or the order or direction has been complied with;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: decide the matter in issue on the basis of the information on the record; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make any order that it considers just and equitable in the circumstances, including a dismissal order.

Section.Text: This Part applies to proceedings in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an appeal from an assessment, reassessment, rejection, decision or determination of the Minister of National Revenue or from a decision or re-determination of the President, as the case may be, pursuant to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 67 of the Customs Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 61 of the Special Import Measures Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: sections 81.19, 81.21, 81.22, 81.23 or 81.33 of the Excise Tax Act, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: sections 13 or 63 of the Energy Administration Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with such modifications as the circumstances require, a re-hearing under subsection 68(2) of the Customs Act or paragraph 62(2)(b) of the Special Import Measures Act and a reference under section 70 of the Customs Act as if they were an appeal.

Subsection.Text: An appeal to the Tribunal shall be commenced by filing a notice of appeal

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with the President and the Tribunal, in the case of an appeal under the Customs Act or the Special Import Measures Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with the Tribunal, in the case of an appeal under the Excise Tax Act or the Energy Administration Act.

Subsection.Text: The notice of appeal shall be accompanied by a copy of the assessment, reassessment, rejection, decision, determination or re-determination, as the case may be, from which the appeal is launched.

If the notice of appeal is filed by mail, the date of filing is the earliest postal date appearing on the envelope containing the document, and, in the absence of a proof of mailing, the date of filing is the date on which the document is received by the Tribunal, as evidenced by the date stamped on it.

Heading.TitleText: Sending of Acknowledgement of Receipt and Notice of Appeal

Section.Text: Except in the case referred to in section 81.25 of the Excise Tax Act, the Tribunal must, without delay after the filing of a notice of appeal, send an acknowledgement of receipt of the notice to the appellant and a copy of the notice to the respondent.

Subsection.Text: The appellant must, within 60 days after receipt of an acknowledgement referred to in section 32,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: file with the Tribunal a brief prepared in accordance with subrules (2) and (3); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to rule 17, serve a copy of the brief without delay on the other parties, and send to the Tribunal a confirmation that the service has been effected.

Subsection.Text: A brief referred to in subrule (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be dated and signed by the appellant or by the appellant’s counsel, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be numbered on each page;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be divided into paragraphs that are numbered consecutively and that set out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement of the grounds for appeal and of the material facts relevant to each ground,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the goods in issue,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement of points in issue between the parties,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the statutory provisions relied on,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the history of the proceeding before the filing of the notice of appeal,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the Tribunal’s jurisdiction to hear the appeal,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief statement of argument to be made at the hearing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the nature of the decision, order, finding or declaration sought;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: include a table of authorities on which the appellant intends to rely and a copy of those authorities that are reasonably necessary in the presentation of the appeal or as otherwise directed by the Tribunal;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: include a copy of any document that may be useful in explaining or supporting the appeal and any other information relating to the appeal that the Tribunal requires; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: contain the name, address for service, telephone number and email address of the appellant and of the appellant’s counsel, if any.

Subsection.Text: An appellant who intends to rely at the hearing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on any documents or authorities that were not available or that could not be included in a brief filed with the Tribunal must, not less than 20 days before the hearing, file them with the Tribunal and, subject to rule 17, serve a copy of them on the other parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on any physical exhibit must, not less than 20 days before the hearing, file it with the Tribunal and notify the other parties of the filing; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on any witness testimony must, not less than 20 days before the hearing, file with the Tribunal a list providing the name and occupation of any proposed witness as well as the language to be used at the hearing.

Subsection.Text: The respondent must, within 60 days after the service of the appellant’s brief under rule 34, file a response with the Tribunal and, subject to rule 17, serve a copy of it on the other parties.
A response referred to in subrule (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be dated and signed by the respondent or the respondent’s counsel, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be numbered on each page;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be divided into paragraphs that are numbered consecutively and that set out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement of the grounds of opposition to the appeal and of the material facts relevant to each ground,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an admission or denial of each ground and of each of the material facts relevant to each ground set out in the appellant’s brief,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the issues to be decided,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the statutory provisions relied on,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the history of the proceeding before the filing of the notice of appeal,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the Tribunal’s jurisdiction to hear the appeal,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief statement of argument to be made at the hearing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: include a table of authorities on which the respondent intends to rely and a copy of those authorities that are reasonably necessary in the presentation of the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: include a copy of any document that may be useful in explaining or supporting the appeal and any other information relating to the appeal that the Tribunal requires; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: contain the name, address for service, telephone number and email address of the respondent and of the respondent’s counsel, if any.

Subsection.Text: A respondent who intends to rely at the hearing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on any documents or authorities that were not available or that could not be included in a response filed with the Tribunal must, not less than 20 days before the hearing, file them with the Tribunal and, subject to rule 17, serve a copy of them on the other parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on any physical exhibit must, not less than 20 days before the hearing, file it with the Tribunal and notify the other parties of the filing; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on any witness testimony must, not less than 20 days before the hearing, file with the Tribunal a list providing the name and occupation of any proposed witness as well as the language to be used at the hearing.

Section.Text: The Tribunal may, at any time, direct a party to file with the Tribunal any written submissions, documents or evidence relating to an appeal.
Where an appeal is to be disposed of by means of a hearing, the Tribunal shall fix a date for the hearing of the appeal.
When the Tribunal has fixed the date for a hearing, it must notify all parties to the appeal and their counsel.

Heading.TitleText: Intervention by Vendor of Goods under Subsection 81.33(9) of the Excise Tax Act

Section.Text: An intervention referred to in subsection 81.33(9) of the Excise Tax Act may be made by filing with the Tribunal a request to intervene.

Heading.TitleText: Contents of a Request To Intervene

Section.Text: A request to intervene must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include the nature of the interest of the person who wishes to be added as an intervener and the manner in which it may be affected;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out a summary of the representations that would be made by the person and why their interest would not otherwise be adequately represented;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: include the manner in which the person may assist the Tribunal in the resolution of the appeal; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: include any other relevant matters.

Subsection.Text: If a person files a request to intervene

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Tribunal must serve a copy of the request to intervene on every person who is a party to the appeal when the notice is filed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the parties to the appeal may make representations in respect of the notice.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal must determine whether to add the person as an intervener on the basis of the information provided by that person under rule 40.1 or any other consideration that the Tribunal considers relevant.
If the Tribunal determines that the person is to be added as an intervener, the Tribunal must so notify the other parties to the appeal.

An intervener is entitled to receive from the Tribunal copies of all of the documents, other than documents which contain confidential information, that were filed by each party to the appeal prior to their being added as an intervener and, subject to rule 16, the counsel or expert for the intervener is entitled to have access to documents which contain confidential information.

Subject to rule 17, each party to the appeal must serve on the intervener copies of all of the documents served by that party on the other parties to the appeal on or after the day they are added as an intervener.
The Tribunal may limit an intervener’s submission to any matter that may assist the Tribunal in the resolution of the appeal.

Section.Text: A party who instituted an appeal may, on or before the day fixed for the commencement of the hearing of the appeal, discontinue the appeal by filing a notice with the Tribunal and by serving without delay a copy of it on the other parties to the appeal.
Where, at a hearing, a party fails to appear, the Tribunal may allow the appeal, dismiss the appeal or give such other direction as is just.

Heading.Label: PART III
Heading.TitleText: References Under Subsection 33(2) of the Special Import Measures Act

Section.Text: This Part applies to a reference made to the Tribunal under subsection 33(2) of the Special Import Measures Act.
A reference shall be made by filing with the Tribunal written notice of the reference of the question to the Tribunal.

Heading.TitleText: Sending of Notice to the President

Section.Text: If a reference is made by a person other than the President, the Tribunal must without delay give to the President written notice of the reference.

Heading.TitleText: Information to be Filed by the President

Section.Text: Where a reference is made in relation to any matter before the President, the President shall file with the Tribunal

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any written complaint made to the President under subsection 31(1) of the Special Import Measures Act in relation to that matter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all information and material relating to that matter that was in the possession of the President when the President made the decision or reached the conclusion as a result of which the question was referred to the Tribunal; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the names and addresses of all persons and governments that, pursuant to that Act, were given notice of the decision or conclusion of the President as a result of which the question was referred to the Tribunal.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal shall render its advice on a reference in writing and give reasons for its advice.
When the Tribunal has rendered its advice, it must without delay send a copy of the advice to the President and to every person and government named in the list referred to in paragraph 51(c).

If the Tribunal terminates proceedings under paragraph 35.1(1)(c) of the Special Import Measures Act, the Tribunal must without delay give notice of the termination to the President and to every person and government named in the list referred to in paragraph 51(c) and in respect of which a notice is not required to be given under paragraph 35.1(2)(a) of that Act.

Heading.Label: PART III.1
Heading.TitleText: Preliminary Inquiries Under Subsection 34(2) of the Special Import Measures Act

Section.Text: This Part applies to a preliminary injury inquiry conducted by the Tribunal under subsection 34(2) of the Special Import Measures Act as a consequence of the receipt of a notice of an initiation of an investigation of dumping or subsidizing in respect of goods.

Heading.TitleText: Notice of Commencement of Preliminary Inquiry

Section.Text: If a notice of initiation of an investigation of dumping or subsidizing is filed with the Tribunal, it must without delay cause to be published in the Canada Gazette a notice of commencement of a preliminary inquiry that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the statutory authority for the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the subject-matter of the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which an interested party must file a notice of participation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which counsel for an interested party must file a notice of representation and, if appropriate, a declaration and undertaking referred to in subrule 16(1);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which any written submissions must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the number of copies of each written submission that must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: instructions with respect to the filing of confidential information;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the address to which written submissions or correspondence may be sent or delivered and at which information in respect of the preliminary inquiry may be obtained; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any other information that the Tribunal considers relevant to the inquiry.

Heading.TitleText: Sending of a Notice of Commencement of Preliminary Inquiry

Section.Text: The Tribunal shall send a copy of a notice of commencement of preliminary inquiry referred to in rule 52.2 to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the President;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all of the persons known to the Tribunal to be interested parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the government of any country from which goods in respect of which the initiation of a dumping or subsidizing investigation was made were exported to Canada.

Heading.TitleText: Information to be Filed by the President

Section.Text: If the President causes an investigation to be initiated respecting the dumping or subsidizing of goods under section 31 of the Special Import Measures Act, the President must file with the Tribunal, in addition to the notice required to be given under paragraph 34(1)(a) of that Act,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the President’s statement of reasons for initiating the investigation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of both the public and, if applicable, confidential version of the written complaint made to the President under subsection 31(1) of the Special Import Measures Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other relevant information that has been taken into consideration by the President.

Section.Text: If the Tribunal causes a preliminary inquiry to be terminated under paragraph 35.1(1)(b) of the Special Import Measures Act, it must give notice of the termination to every person and government referred to in rule 52.3 and in respect of which a notice is not required to be given under paragraph 35.1(2)(a) of that Act.

Heading.Label: PART IV
Heading.TitleText: Inquiries Under Section 42 of the Special Import Measures Act

Section.Text: This Part applies to an inquiry, in respect of injury or retardation or threat of injury, made by the Tribunal under section 42 of the Special Import Measures Act as a consequence of the receipt of a notice of a preliminary determination of dumping or subsidizing in respect of goods.

If a notice of a preliminary determination of dumping or subsidizing is filed with the Tribunal under the Special Import Measures Act, the Tribunal must without delay cause to be published in the Canada Gazette a notice of commencement of inquiry that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the statutory authority for the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the subject-matter of the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which an interested party must file a notice of participation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which counsel for an interested party must file a notice of representation and, if appropriate, a declaration and undertaking referred to in subrule 16(1);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which an interested person may file written representations under subsection 45(6) of that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which any written submissions must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the number of copies of each written submission that must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: instructions with respect to the filing of confidential information;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the address to which written submissions or correspondence may be sent or delivered and at which information in respect of the inquiry may be obtained;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the place and time fixed for the commencement of a hearing in the inquiry; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: any other information that the Tribunal considers relevant to the inquiry.

Heading.TitleText: Sending of a Notice of Commencement of Inquiry

Section.Text: The Tribunal shall send a copy of a notice of commencement of inquiry referred to in rule 54 to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the President;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all of the persons known by the Tribunal to be interested parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the government of any country from which goods in respect of which the preliminary determination was made were exported to Canada.

Heading.TitleText: Information to be Filed by the President — Preliminary Determination

Section.Text: If the President makes a preliminary determination of dumping or subsidizing with respect to goods under section 38 of the Special Import Measures Act, the President must cause to be filed with the Tribunal, in addition to the written notice referred to in paragraph 38(3)(b) of that Act, the following materials:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the preliminary determination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed statement of all estimates and of all things specified by the President pursuant to paragraph 38(1)(a) or (b) of that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a document that contains information with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: domestic producers, importers into Canada and exporters to Canada of such goods who are known to the President, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the volume of the goods imported into Canada and the proportion of those goods found by the President to be dumped or subsidized; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: such other materials that contain information with respect to any matter referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (c) as is in the President’s possession and as the Tribunal may from time to time request.

Heading.TitleText: Information to be Filed by the President — Final Determination

Section.Text: If the President makes a final determination of dumping or subsidizing with respect to goods under section 41 of the Special Import Measures Act, the President must cause to be filed with the Tribunal, in addition to the written notice referred to in subsection 41(3) of that Act, the following materials:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the final determination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed statement of all estimates and of all things specified by the President pursuant to subsection 41(1) of that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a document that contains information with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: domestic producers, importers into Canada and exporters to Canada of such goods who are known to the President, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the volume of the goods imported into Canada and the proportion of those goods found by the President to be dumped or subsidized;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: documents setting out the margin of dumping in relation to the goods that are imported into Canada from each country subject to an inquiry, which margin of dumping is the weighted average of the margins of dumping determined in accordance with section 30.2 of the Special Import Measures Act expressed as a percentage of the export price of the good;

Paragraph.Label: (c.2)
Paragraph.Text: documents setting out the amount of subsidy in relation to the goods that are imported into Canada from each country subject to an inquiry, expressed as a percentage of the export price of the goods; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: such other materials that contain information with respect to any matter referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (c) as is in the President’s possession and as the Tribunal may from time to time request.

Heading.TitleText: Information to be Provided by the Tribunal

Section.Text: In any inquiry, the Tribunal shall, forthwith after expiration of the date on or before which interested parties or counsel for the interested parties are required to file a Notice of Appearance, provide each counsel and, where a party to the inquiry is not represented by counsel, that party, with the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the names and addresses of all parties to the inquiry and their counsel, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the codes assigned to the parties’ exhibits; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure for the filing of documents.

Section.Text: In an inquiry, the Tribunal must, after the expiry of the day on or before which interested parties are required to file a notice of participation, make available, on any conditions that are established by the Tribunal under subsection 45(3) of the Act,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to each counsel who has filed a declaration and undertaking referred to in subrule 16(1) and who has been granted access to the confidential information, all of the confidential information provided to the Tribunal for the purposes of the inquiry; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to all counsel and to any party who is not represented by counsel, all of the information provided to the Tribunal for the purposes of the inquiry that has not been designated as confidential.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may at any time direct any party to an inquiry to file with the Tribunal, on or before a date fixed by the Tribunal, the following material:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: written submissions, documents or evidence relating to the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the evidence adduced or to be adduced by the party; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any exhibit in other than documentary form that the party intends to adduce at the inquiry.

Subsection.Text: In the case of an inquiry under section 31 of the Special Import Measures Act, the date fixed for the filing of the material referred to in subrule (1) by any party other than the complainant or other person referred to in that section shall be later than the date fixed under that subrule for the filing of the material by the complainant or other person.

Heading.TitleText: Information to be Provided by Parties

Section.Text: In considering an issue of injury or retardation or threat of injury, the Tribunal may at any time direct a party to an inquiry to produce information that relates to the factors prescribed by section 37.1 of the Special Import Measures Regulations.

Subsection.Text: In this rule, a request for information includes a request for the production of a document.
A party may direct a request for information to any other party.

A party that makes a request for information shall file the request with the Tribunal and serve it on the other parties within any time that the considerations of fairness and efficiency permit and that the Tribunal may direct.
A request for information shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in writing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out the name of the party to whom it is addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: number each request for information consecutively;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: explain how the request is relevant or necessary to the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be dated.

Subsection.Text: If the party to whom the request is addressed refuses to give some or all of the information requested, that party must, within any time that the considerations of fairness and efficiency permit and that the Tribunal may direct,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the party contends that some or all of the information requested is not relevant or necessary, give reasons in support of that contention;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the party contends that some or all of the information requested is not available, give reasons for its unavailability and provide any other available information or documents that are of the same nature and to the same effect as the requested information; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the party makes any other contention, including a contention based on criteria referred to in paragraphs (7)(c) to (f), give reasons in support of that contention.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal may, on its own initiative or on the request of a party, refuse the request or grant all or part of it on the basis of criteria set out in subrule (7).
For the purpose of subrule (6), the Tribunal shall take the following criteria into account:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the relevance and necessity of the information requested;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any contentions referred to in subrule (5);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the sufficiency of the information already on the record;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the availability of the information from other sources;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the ability or inability of the party to respond; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter relevant to the request.

Subsection.Text: If the Tribunal orders the party to whom the request is addressed to provide some or all of the information requested, the party shall, within any time that the considerations of fairness and efficiency permit and that the Tribunal may direct,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: serve on the other party

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a full and adequate response, in writing, for each question in the request,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a signed declaration that the responses are complete and correct to the best of the information and belief of the party providing the response, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the information requested, or copies of it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: file with the Tribunal copies of the responses and information in the number that it indicates are necessary for it and the interested parties.

Subsection.Text: A party to whom a request for information is directed complies with the order of the Tribunal if the party indicates to the other party which of its records contain the relevant information and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the party specifies in sufficient detail where the information may be found;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the burden of obtaining the information is substantially the same for either party; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the party directing the request is given a reasonable opportunity to examine the records and make copies or summaries of them.

Subsection.Text: If a party files a response or documents that contain confidential information, the party who provides the confidential information shall, within any time that the considerations of fairness and efficiency permit and that the Tribunal may direct, file a non-confidential edited version or a non-confidential summary of the response in accordance with paragraph 46(1)(b) of the Act.
If a party to whom a request for information is directed does not comply with this rule, the party who directed the request for information may request the Tribunal to order compliance.

A party who wishes to have supplementary information relating to submissions, evidence and responses to requests for information that are filed with the Tribunal by another party shall serve a notice on all of the parties before the start of a hearing, within the period that the Tribunal may direct, to have the other party answer questions or provide documents or other information at the hearing concerning the matters arising from the material filed.
A party who makes a request shall file the notice with the Tribunal.
The notice shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in writing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify the party who will be required to answer questions or bring specified documents or information;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: number each matter consecutively;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: specify the information or documents requested, with an explanation of how they are relevant or necessary to the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be dated.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal shall notify the parties in writing on which matters they must be prepared to answer questions at the hearing and specify which documents, if any, that they must be prepared to bring with them to the hearing.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Filed by Tribunal — Advice Under Section 46 of Special Import Measures Act

Section.Text: If the Tribunal advises the President under section 46 of the Special Import Measures Act, it must cause to be filed with the President, in addition to the written notice referred to in that section, a copy of the information relied on in giving its advice.

Heading.Label: PART V
Heading.TitleText: Recommencement of Inquiry Under Section 44 of the Special Import Measures Act

Section.Text: This Part applies to the recommencement of an inquiry made by the Tribunal under paragraph 44(1)(a) or (b) of the Special Import Measures Act where, pursuant to an application for judicial review under the Federal Courts Act or an application under section 96.1 of the Special Import Measures Act, an order or finding of the Tribunal is set aside or is set aside in relation to particular goods.

Where an inquiry is recommenced pursuant to subsection 44(1) of the Special Import Measures Act, the Tribunal shall forthwith cause to be published in the Canada Gazette a notice of recommencement of inquiry setting out, with such modifications as the circumstances require, the same information as is referred to in paragraphs 54(a) to (k).
The Tribunal shall forthwith send a copy of the notice of recommencement of inquiry referred to in rule 65 to the persons referred to in paragraph 44(2)(a) of the Special Import Measures Act.

Where an order or finding of the Tribunal is set aside or is set aside in relation to particular goods pursuant to an application for judicial review under the Federal Courts Act or an application under section 96.1 of the Special Import Measures Act but the matter is not referred back to the Tribunal for determination, any person interested in making any written submission on the question of whether the Tribunal should recommence the inquiry in accordance with paragraph 44(1)(b) of the Special Import Measures Act shall file a submission within 21 days after the final disposition of the application.
Subject to any direction or order of the Tribunal, Part IV applies, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to a recommencement of an inquiry.

Heading.Label: PART V.1
Heading.TitleText: Public Interest Inquiry Under Section 45 of the Special Import Measures Act

Subsection.Text: If a public interest inquiry is initiated arising out of a finding of injury as a result of an inquiry referred to in section 42 of the Special Import Measures Act, the Tribunal shall forthwith cause to be published in the Canada Gazette a notice of commencement of inquiry that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the statutory authority for the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the subject-matter of the inquiry, together with any other relevant details of the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which an interested party or interested person must file a notice of participation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which counsel for an interested party or interested person, if any, must file a notice of representation and, if appropriate, a declaration and undertaking referred to in subrule 16(1);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which any written submissions must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the number of copies of each written submission that must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: instructions with respect to the filing of confidential information;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the date, place and time fixed for the commencement of a hearing in the inquiry; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any other information that the Tribunal considers relevant to the inquiry.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal shall send a copy of a notice of commencement of inquiry referred to in subrule (1) to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the President;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all of the persons known by the Tribunal to be interested parties or interested persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the government of any country from which goods in respect of which the final determination was made were exported to Canada.

Heading.TitleText: Information to be Provided by the Tribunal

Section.Text: The Tribunal shall, forthwith after the expiry of the date on or before which interested parties or interested persons are required to file a notice of participation or counsel for them is required to file a notice of representation, provide each counsel and, where an interested party or interested person is not represented by counsel, that interested party or interested person, with the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the names and addresses of all parties and interested persons to the inquiry and their counsel, if any; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the procedure for the filing of documents.

Section.Text: The Tribunal may at any time direct any party or interested person to a public interest inquiry to file with the Tribunal, on or before a date fixed by the Tribunal, the following material:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: written submissions, documents or evidence relating to the inquiry;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the evidence adduced or to be adduced by the party or interested person; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any exhibit in other than documentary form that the party or interested person intends to adduce at the inquiry.

Heading.TitleText: Additional Information to be Provided by Parties or Interested Persons

Section.Text: The Tribunal may at any time direct a party or interested person to a public interest inquiry to produce any additional information that relates to any factors or that it considers relevant to the inquiry.

If the President makes a finding that there is circumvention under subsection 75.1(1) of the Special Import Measures Act, the decision filed with the Tribunal must be accompanied by the record of the decision and the statement of essential facts on which the determination was based.

Heading.Label: PART VI
Heading.TitleText: Reviews Under Sections 76.01, 76.02, 76.03 and 76.1 of the Special Import Measures Act

Section.Text: This Part applies in respect of a review of an order or finding by the Tribunal

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under subsection 76.01(1), 76.02(1) or 76.03(3) of the Special Import Measures Act, whether on the Tribunal’s own initiative or at the request of the President or any other person or of any government;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under subsection 76.02(3) of that Act, if the order or finding is referred back to the Tribunal under an order made by a panel under subsection 77.015(3) or (4), 77.019(5), 77.15(3) or (4) or 77.19(4) of that Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: under subsection 76.1(2) of that Act.

Heading.TitleText: Review under Section 76.01 or 76.02 of the Special Import Measures Act

Subsection.Text: A request by a person to the Tribunal for a review under subsection 76.01(1) or 76.02(1) of the Special Import Measures Act must set out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address for service, telephone number and fax number, if any, of the person making the request and of their counsel, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of their interest in the order or finding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the grounds on which the person believes initiation of the review is warranted and a statement of the facts on which the grounds are based; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the order or finding that the person believes the Tribunal should make under subsection 76.01(5) or 76.02(4) of the Special Import Measures Act on completion of the review.

Subsection.Text: On receipt of a properly documented request referred to in subrule (1), the Tribunal shall inform each party to the inquiry or review that resulted in the order or finding of its receipt of the request and shall give them an opportunity to make representations to the Tribunal concerning the request.

If the Tribunal decides to review an order or a finding under subsection 76.01(1) or 76.02(1) of the Special Import Measures Act, the Tribunal shall forthwith cause to be published in the Canada Gazette a notice of review that sets out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the statutory authority for the review;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the subject-matter of the review, together with any other relevant details of the review;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which an interested party must file a notice of participation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which counsel for an interested party must file a notice of representation and, if appropriate, a declaration and undertaking referred to in subrule 16(1);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which any written submissions must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the number of copies of each written submission that must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: instructions with respect to the filing of confidential information;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the address to which written submissions or correspondence may be sent or delivered and at which information in respect of the review may be obtained; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the place and time fixed for commencement of a hearing in the review.

Subsection.Text: The Tribunal must send a copy of a notice of review to each person to whom and government to which it would be required by rule 55 to send a copy of the notice of commencement of inquiry if the review were an inquiry referred to in rule 53.

Section.Text: In order to decide whether an interim review under section 76.01 of the Special Import Measures Act is warranted, the Tribunal may request the parties to provide information concerning

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether changed circumstances or new facts have arisen since the making of the order or finding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: facts that were not put in evidence in the original proceedings and that were not discoverable by the exercise of reasonable diligence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that is relevant to the review.

Section.Text: For the purposes of subsections 76.01(6) and 76.02(5) of the Special Import Measures Act, the other persons to whom and governments to which a copy of the order or finding and reasons for it must be forwarded are the persons — other than the President — and governments who received a copy of the notice of review.

Heading.TitleText: Review under Section 76.03 of the Special Import Measures Act

Subsection.Text: When an order or a finding is deemed to be rescinded on the expiry of a five-year period in accordance with subsection 76.03(1) of the Special Import Measures Act, the notice of expiry that the Tribunal must cause to be published in the Canada Gazette in accordance with subsection 76.03(2) of that Act shall set out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the order or finding will be deemed to be rescinded;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date on or before which any written submissions must be filed by any person or government requesting or opposing the initiation of a review of the order or finding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of copies of each written submission that must be filed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: instructions with respect to the filing of confidential information; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the address to which written submissions or correspondence may be sent or delivered and at which information in respect of the expiry may be obtained.

Subsection.Text: After the publication of a notice of expiry referred to in subrule (1), the Tribunal must, if it does not receive a request for a review from a person or government and it decides not to initiate a review on its own initiative under subsection 76.03(3) of the Special Import Measures Act, advise the interested parties of that decision.

If the Tribunal decides to initiate a review, the information that must be included in a notice of the initiation of a review that the Tribunal must cause to be published in the Canada Gazette, in accordance with subsection 76.03(6) of the Special Import Measures Act, is the information specified in subrule 71(1).

The Tribunal must send a copy of a notice of expiry to each person to whom and government to which it would be required by rule 55 to send a copy of the notice of commencement of inquiry if the review were an inquiry referred to in rule 53.
